H0.text: Carbon dioxide is the substance in the atmosphere that forms the crystals on which light reflects to produce halos.

H1.text: Oxygen is the substance in the atmosphere that forms the crystals that produce halos when light reflects off them.

H2.text: Sulfur dioxide is the substance that forms the atmospheric crystals whose reflection of light produces halo effects.

H3.text: Water forms the crystals in the atmosphere that produce halos when light reflects off them.

A4.text: Ice crystals create optical phenomena like diamond dust and halos in the sky due to light reflecting off of the crystals in a process called scattering.

A5.text: Ice crystals are responsible for various atmospheric optical displays and cloud formations.
